facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 433 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 433 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 24, 1956, of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in Civil Misc. Case No. 17 of 1955

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 24, 1956, of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in Civil Misc. Case No. 17 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on October 17, 1958 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan

facts.text: Appellant is a resident of what was once the independent State of Udaipur

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a resident of what was once the independent State of Udaipur. There was in that State a Company called the Mewar Industries, Ltd.,

facts.text: Mewar Industries, Ltd. registered under the provisions of the law in force in State of Udaipur

anchor.surface_text: There was in that State a Company called the Mewar Industries, Ltd., registered under the provisions of the law in force in that State,

facts.text: Appellant held 266 shares in Mewar Industries Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: registered under the provisions of the law in force in that State, and the appellant held 266 shares in that Company.

facts.text: Company went into liquidation on January 18, 1950

anchor.surface_text: On January 18, 1950, the Company went into liquidation, and on April 22, 1950, the liquidator distributed a portion of the assets

facts.text: Liquidator distributed assets to shareholders on April 22, 1950, appellant paid Rs. 26,000

anchor.surface_text: and on April 22, 1950, the liquidator distributed a portion of the assets among the shareholders, and the appellant was paid a sum of Rs. 26,000

facts.text: Rs. 26,000 represents undistributed profits accrued during six accounting years preceding liquidation, on common ground

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that this sum represents the undistributed profits of the Company which had accrued during the six accounting years preceding the liquidation.

facts.text: No law imposing tax on income in State of Udaipur before Indian Finance Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned that there was in the State of Udaipur numberlaw imposing tax on income, and that it was only under the Indian Finance Act, 1950

facts.text: Indian Finance Act, 1950 came into force on April 1, 1950, making residents of Rajasthan liable to income tax

anchor.surface_text: that the residents of the State of Rajasthan, in which the State of Udaipur had merged, became liable for the first time to pay tax on their income. That Act came into force on April 1, 1950.

facts.text: Concerned with assessment for year 1951-52 on income of previous year 1950-51 under s. 3 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in these proceedings with the assessment of tax for the year 1951-52, and that, under s. 3 of the Act, has to be on the income of the previous year, i.e., 1950-51.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 26,000 as dividend u/s 2(6A)(c) by order dated July 3, 1952 and included in taxable income

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated July 3, 1952, the Income-tax Officer held that this was dividend as defined in s. 2 6A  c  of the Act and included it in the taxable income of the appellant in the year of account.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed assessment by order dated January 12, 1953

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took this order in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who by his order dated January 12, 1953, companyfirmed the assessment.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal dismissed appeal on November 10, 1953

anchor.surface_text: There was a further appeal by the appellant to the Appellate Tribunal, who also dismissed it on November 10, 1953.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal referred question to High Court on application of appellant

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the appellant, the Appellate Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case,

facts.text: High Court answered the question in affirmative by judgment dated August 24, 1956

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Wanchoo, C. J. and Modi, J. who by their judgment dated August 24, 1956, answered it in the affirmative.

facts.text: Present appeal preferred on certificate granted by High Court under s. 66A(2)

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment that the present appeal has been -preferred on a certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66A 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Profits distributed accumulated during years 1943-44 to 1948-49, not in dispute

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that the profits which were distributed had been accumulated during the years 1943-44 to 1948-49, i.e., during the six years preceding the liquida- tion.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Rs. 26,000 received on April 22, 1950 is dividend u/s 2(6A)(c)

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, ,as dividend as defined in s. 2 6A   c  of the Act and is chargeable to tax.

facts.text: Whether Mewar Industries Ltd. was a company u/s 2(6) disputed, as it turns on disputed question of fact

anchor.surface_text: whether the Mewar Industries Ltd., is a Company as defined in the Indian Income-tax Act is itself a question over which the parties are in companytroversy.

facts.text: Indian Companies Act came into operation in Udaipur territory on April 1, 1951 by Part B States Laws Act

anchor.surface_text: that the Indian Companies Act came into operation in the Udaipur territory on April 1, 1951, only by force of the Part B Stater, Laws Act  111 of 1951

1958. October 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.
We are companycerned in these proceedings with the assessment of tax for the year 1951-52, and that, under s. 3 of the Act, has to be on the income of the previous year, i.e., 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: That definition, as it stood on the relevant date and omitting what is number material, was in these terms 6 A  dividend includes-  a  any distribution by a companypany of accumulated profits whether capitalised or number if such distribution entails the release by the companypany to its shareholders of all or any part of the assets of the companypany  c  any distribution made to the shareholders of a companypany out of accumulated profits of the companypany on the liquidation of the companypany Provided that only the accumulated profits so distributed which arose during the six previous years of the companypany preceding the date of liquidation shall be so included.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the aforesaid sum of Rs. 26,000 was liable to be taxed in the assessees hands as dividend within the meaning of that term in s. 2 6A c of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the appellant, the Appellate Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the aforesaid sum of Rs. 26,000 was liable to be taxed in the assessees hands as dividend within the meaning of that term in s. 2 6A c of the Indian Income-tax Act.

issues.text: whether the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, is dividend as defined in s. 2 6A c of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in this appeal is whether the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, is dividend as defined in. s. 2 6A c of the Act.

issues.text: whether those years can be said to be previous years within s. 2 6A c of the Act

anchor.surface_text: those profits had not been accumulated within the six previous years of the liquidation of the Company. It is not in dispute that the profits which were distributed had been accumulated during the years 1943-44 to 1948-49, i.e., during the six years preceding the liquida- tion. The point in controversy is whether those years can be said to be previous years within s. 2 6A c of the Act.

issues.text: The question is which of these two interpretations is the right one to be put on the language of s. 2 6A c

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent which has been accepted by the Income-tax authorities and by the learned Judges in the Court below is that the expression six previous years is used in s. 2 6A c not in the technical and restricted sense in which the words previous year are used in s. 2 11 of the Act, and that, in the context, it means six consecutive accounting years preceding the liquidation of the company. The question is which of these two interpretations is the right one to be put on the language of s. 2 6A c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expression 'six previous years' means six accounting years preceding liquidation; s.2(11) definition repugnant to context as only one previous year per assessment year

holdings.text: it would be repugnant to the definition of dividend in s. 2(6A)(c) to import into the words 'six previous years' the definition of 'previous year' in s. 2(11) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that it would be repugnant to the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  c  to import into the words six previous years the definition of previous year in s. 2 l 1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(11) defines singular 'previous year' relative to one assessment year; applying to 'six previous years' creates contradiction

holdings.text: to read 'a previous year' in s. 2(11) would be to nullify the 'previous year' enacted therein, and such a construction must therefore be rejected as repugnant to the context

anchor.surface_text: But s. 13 only enacts a rule of companystruction which is to apply unless there is anything repugnant in the and to read a previous year in s. 2 l 1  would be to nullify the previous year enacted therein,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.13(2) General Clauses Act rule that singular includes plural repugnant here as it nullifies specific singular definition in s.2(11)

holdings.text: while there may be several preceding years to a given year of assessment there can be only one previous year in relation to it, and that it would make no sense to speak of six previous years with reference to a year of assessment

anchor.surface_text: But this argument overlooks that while there may be several preceding years to a given year of assessment there can be only one previous year in relation to it,

holdings.text: the point turns on disputed question of fact, it cannot be allowed to be raised at this stage

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. K. Srinivasan and K. Gopalan  1 . There, the point for decision was as to the interpretation to be put on the words end of the previous year in s. 25, sub-ss.  3  and  4  of the Act which dealt with discontinuance of or succession to a business, and it was held that the expression previous year in those provisions meant an accounting year expiring immediately preceding the date of discontinuance or succession.

precedents.cited_proposition: previous year can mean an accounting year immediately preceding the happening of a contingency, not necessarily tied to an assessment year
precedents.cited_holding: the expression previous year in s. 25(3) and (4) meant an accounting year expiring immediately preceding the date of discontinuance or succession
